segment.source: Network access Do not allow storage of passwords and credentials for network authentication (Windows 10)
segment.target: Network access Do not allow storage of passwords and credentials for network authentication (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the Network access Do not allow storage of passwords and credentials for network authentication security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the Network access Do not allow storage of passwords and credentials for network authentication security policy setting.

segment.source: Network access: Do not allow storage of passwords and credentials for network authentication
segment.target: Network access: Do not allow storage of passwords and credentials for network authentication

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the Network access: Do not allow storage of passwords and credentials for network authentication security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the Network access: Do not allow storage of passwords and credentials for network authentication security policy setting.

segment.source: Reference
segment.target: Reference

segment.source: This security setting determines whether Credential Manager saves passwords and credentials for later use when it gains domain authentication.
segment.target: This security setting determines whether Credential Manager saves passwords and credentials for later use when it gains domain authentication.

segment.source: Possible values
segment.target: Possible values

segment.source: Enabled
segment.target: Enabled

segment.source: Credential Manager does not store passwords and credentials on the device
segment.target: Credential Manager does not store passwords and credentials on the device

segment.source: Disabled
segment.target: Disabled

segment.source: Credential Manager will store passwords and credentials on this computer for later use for domain authentication.
segment.target: Credential Manager will store passwords and credentials on this computer for later use for domain authentication.

segment.source: Not defined
segment.target: Not defined

segment.source: Best practices
segment.target: Best practices

segment.source: It is a recommended practice to disable the ability of the Windows operating system to cache credentials on any device where credentials are not needed.
segment.target: It is a recommended practice to disable the ability of the Windows operating system to cache credentials on any device where credentials are not needed.

segment.source: Evaluate your servers and workstations to determine the requirements.
segment.target: Evaluate your servers and workstations to determine the requirements.

segment.source: Cached credentials are designed primarily to be used on laptops that require domain credentials when disconnected from the domain.
segment.target: Cached credentials are designed primarily to be used on laptops that require domain credentials when disconnected from the domain.

segment.source: Location
segment.target: Location

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.target: Default values

segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.target: Server type or Group Policy Object (GPO)

segment.target: Default domain policy

segment.target: Disabled

segment.target: Default domain controller policy

segment.target: Disabled

segment.target: Stand-alone server default settings

segment.target: Disabled

segment.target: Domain controller effective default settings

segment.target: Not defined

segment.target: Member server effective default settings

segment.target: Effective GPO default settings on client computers

segment.source: Policy management
segment.target: Policy management

segment.source: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Restart requirement
segment.target: Restart requirement

segment.source: A restart of the device is required before this policy will be effective when changes to this policy are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: A restart of the device is required before this policy will be effective when changes to this policy are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: Group Policy
segment.target: Group Policy

segment.source: This policy setting can be configured by using the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) to be distributed through Group Policy Objects (GPOs).
segment.target: This policy setting can be configured by using the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) to be distributed through Group Policy Objects (GPOs).

segment.source: If this policy is not contained in a distributed GPO, this policy can be configured on the local computer by using the Local Security Policy snap-in.
segment.target: If this policy is not contained in a distributed GPO, this policy can be configured on the local computer by using the Local Security Policy snap-in.

segment.source: Security considerations
segment.target: Security considerations

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: Vulnerability
segment.target: Vulnerability

segment.source: Passwords that are cached can be accessed by the user when logged on to the device.
segment.target: Passwords that are cached can be accessed by the user when logged on to the device.

segment.source: Although this information may sound obvious, a problem can arise if the user unknowingly runs malicious software that reads the passwords and forwards them to another, unauthorized user.
segment.target: Although this information may sound obvious, a problem can arise if the user unknowingly runs malicious software that reads the passwords and forwards them to another, unauthorized user.

segment.source: Note: The chances of success for this exploit and others that involve malicious software are reduced significantly for organizations that effectively implement and manage an enterprise antivirus solution combined with sensible software restriction policies.
segment.target: Note: The chances of success for this exploit and others that involve malicious software are reduced significantly for organizations that effectively implement and manage an enterprise antivirus solution combined with sensible software restriction policies.

segment.source: Regardless of what encryption algorithm is used to encrypt the password verifier, a password verifier can be overwritten so that an attacker can authenticate as the user to whom the verifier belongs.
segment.target: Regardless of what encryption algorithm is used to encrypt the password verifier, a password verifier can be overwritten so that an attacker can authenticate as the user to whom the verifier belongs.

segment.source: Therefore, the administrator's password may be overwritten.
segment.target: Therefore, the administrator's password may be overwritten.

segment.source: This procedure requires physical access to the device.
segment.target: This procedure requires physical access to the device.

segment.source: Utilities exist that can help overwrite the cached verifier.
segment.target: Utilities exist that can help overwrite the cached verifier.

segment.source: By using one of these utilities, an attacker can authenticate by using the overwritten value.
segment.target: By using one of these utilities, an attacker can authenticate by using the overwritten value.

segment.source: Overwriting the administrator's password does not help the attacker access data that is encrypted by using that password.
segment.target: Overwriting the administrator's password does not help the attacker access data that is encrypted by using that password.

segment.source: Also, overwriting the password does not help the attacker access any Encrypting File System (EFS) data that belongs to other users on that device.
segment.target: Also, overwriting the password does not help the attacker access any Encrypting File System (EFS) data that belongs to other users on that device.

segment.source: Overwriting the password does not help an attacker replace the verifier, because the base keying material is incorrect.
segment.target: Overwriting the password does not help an attacker replace the verifier, because the base keying material is incorrect.

segment.source: Therefore, data that is encrypted by using Encrypting File System or by using the Data Protection API (DPAPI) will not decrypt.
segment.target: Therefore, data that is encrypted by using Encrypting File System or by using the Data Protection API (DPAPI) will not decrypt.

segment.source: Countermeasure
segment.target: Countermeasure

segment.source: Enable the Network access: Do not allow storage of passwords and credentials for network authentication setting.
segment.target: Enable the Network access: Do not allow storage of passwords and credentials for network authentication setting.

segment.source: To limit the number of changed domain credentials that are stored on the computer, set the cachedlogonscount registry entry.
segment.target: To limit the number of changed domain credentials that are stored on the computer, set the cachedlogonscount registry entry.

segment.source: By default, the operating system caches the verifier for each unique user's ten most recent valid logons.
segment.target: By default, the operating system caches the verifier for each unique user's ten most recent valid logons.

segment.source: This value can be set to any value between 0 and 50.
segment.target: This value can be set to any value between 0 and 50.

segment.source: By default, all versions of the Windows operating system remember 10 cached logons, except Windows Server 2008 and later, which are set at 25.
segment.target: By default, all versions of the Windows operating system remember 10 cached logons, except Windows Server 2008 and later, which are set at 25.

segment.source: When you try to log on to a domain from a Windows-based client device, and a domain controller is unavailable, you do not receive an error message.
segment.target: When you try to log on to a domain from a Windows-based client device, and a domain controller is unavailable, you do not receive an error message.

segment.source: Therefore, you may not notice that you logged on with cached domain credentials.
segment.target: Therefore, you may not notice that you logged on with cached domain credentials.

segment.source: You can set a notification of logon that uses cached domain credentials with the ReportDC registry entry.
segment.target: You can set a notification of logon that uses cached domain credentials with the ReportDC registry entry.

segment.source: Potential impact
segment.target: Potential impact

segment.source: Users are forced to type passwords whenever they log on to their Microsoft Account or other network resources that are not accessible to their domain account.
segment.target: Users are forced to type passwords whenever they log on to their Microsoft Account or other network resources that are not accessible to their domain account.

segment.source: This policy setting should have no impact on users who access network resources that are configured to allow access with their Active Directory–based domain account.
segment.target: This policy setting should have no impact on users who access network resources that are configured to allow access with their Active Directory–based domain account.

segment.target: Related topics
